subject: Physical Fitness
title: Roman Legions and Marching Fitness
description: A micro-lesson that makes Roman Legions and Marching Fitness usable.

hook.text: Roman soldiers marched 30 km a day carrying 30 kg of gear. They built an empire one step at a time.

buildup.text: Legion training included running, swimming, weapons drills, and construction. Soldiers built roads and forts.

discovery.text: Recruits trained with wooden weapons twice the weight of real ones. When battle came, real swords felt light.

twist.text: The term 'military press' originated from soldiers pressing supplies overhead. Exercise names echo military roots.

climax.text: Roman military fitness principles â€” progressive overload, structured training â€” are still used in modern armies.

punchline.text: Roman soldiers were professional athletes in armor. Their methods still work.

quiz.question: Why did Roman recruits train with heavier wooden weapons?
options: So real weapons would feel lighter in battle
Wood was the only available material
